tags: those are just passing mentions though
i had that little Peter monolouge in my head and really wanted to write it out lest I forget it
summary: “You never leave someone for dead.” Peter said softly, tilting his head a bit as he looked down at the Green Goblin, webbed down...
body:
“You never leave someone for dead.” Peter said softly, tilting his head a bit as he looked down at the Green Goblin, webbed down to the corner of the wall. He struggled fruitlessly as Peter stepped forwards. There was a gash in Peter’s side, bleeding down his suit, a bullet wound through his shoulder, and a few various other wounds that came from these fights. 

The difference from the other fights he had had with the man, was the Goblin had figured out who he was. Peter wasn’t quite sure how he managed it, but he had somehow, and thus gone after people Peter cared about. 

He had managed to hide most of them… but never thought about Johnny. 

Johnny Storm, of course, wasn’t on his radar to protect. True, they had recently started dating, but when someone could turn to flame, you never really think about having to protect them, until they’re stumbling into the Baxter building clutching their stomach as they bleed from what could only be a sword wound straight through. Peter… didn’t want to think about it. 

He crouched in front of the stuck Goblin, who snarled at him, but Peter didn’t seem to notice. Instead, he took his hand, shoving it against his nose, placing the exit of the wed shooter’s right against the Green Goblin’s mouth. 

“When I fight you… I’m not angry. I’m scared out of my mind, worried for the people around, but never truly angry. I guess you could say I’m like the Hulk in a way. You don’t like me when I’m angry…” He smiled sadly, tilting his head. “And you, my friend, have sincerely pissed me off.” Goblin’s eyes widened a bit, but showed no other outside fear. 

“I could fill your lungs with webbing in two or three seconds. Fill them up, and you die. These babies are the heavy duty ones. They don’t dissolve for a full twenty-four hours. By that time, you’d be long dead. I could kill you here and now, if I truly wanted to, because you pissed me off. I know you went after Torch. How do I know that? He told me. He didn’t die. That’s why you don’t leave someone for dead… Because they come back, and it bites you hard in the ass.” 

Carefully, Peter moved his hand away from the Goblin’s face, tilting his head a bit. “You’ll be stuck here… for awhile…” The cops won’t be able to get you out. I webbed up any bleeding so you won’t die… but if you know what’s good for you, you’ll stop coming back. You’ll stay in your little cell and wither away, because the alternative?” He held up his hand again, the web shooter glinting slightly. “Is not pretty.” 

Peter stood, placing a hand on his side, letting out a huff. Still bleeding. That wasn’t good. He spared another glance at the Goblin, raising an eyebrow. “You know who I am. If you get out, and get the bright idea to go after someone I care about again… I’ll break my one rule, and you will not be found again.” The threat was obvious as he crawled outside past the Goblin’s line of sight

He lifted his head, hearing the sirens outside. Good. They made it in time. Carefully, Peter crawled up the wall, through a hole in the side of the building, seeing the cops gathering around. He waved at one, dripping blood down to the ground below, before swinging off, trying to calm down properly. 

He’d never tell what he said that made the Goblin so scared of him, and, apparently, the Goblin never did either, as he sat alone in the Raft, never trying to get out again. He was properly scared by Peter. He had seen his eyes, saw how truthful he was being, and didn’t want to face that again, trying to get through to any other villain to just leave it be, leave him be. 

The citizens of New York had no clue how lucky they were that Spider Man was a hero.

summary:
Peter B., holding up a bracelet: MJ, I got you a little present.
MJ: Oh, a friendship bracelet.
Peter B.: Oh, it's just a little...
body:
Peter B., holding up a bracelet: MJ, I got you a little present.

MJ: Oh, a friendship bracelet.

Peter B.: Oh, it’s just a little thing to remind you I’m gonna be here for you, no matter what, forever more.

Peter B., putting the bracelet on MJ’s wrist: No biggie.

MJ: *smiles*

Peter B.: Take it off, I die.

summary: I was thinking about Spiderverse last night, as you do, and Miles' father's name was bugging the shit out of me. (It has been...
body:
I was thinking about Spiderverse last night, as you do, and Miles’ father’s name was bugging the shit out of me. (It has been for a while but I’ve been busy.) I was like “his name is bad, why is his name bad?”

And then I realized “Oh right! Jefferson Davis was PRESIDENT OF THE FUCKING CONFEDERACY!”

Miles’ dad, Jefferson Davis, who is a black man (and police officer in New York, which is uncomfortable enough as it is) shares a name with the president of the Confederate States.

Brian Michael Bendis named a black man after a slave owning monster who, by the way? Was never even tried for treason. He died of natural causes at 81, while holding his wife’s hands. I wonder how many of his slaves had that opportunity?

Apparently the character was named after one of Bendis’ friends, and somehow didn’t see problems with the implications???? (Also who the hell are you hanging outwith that their name their kid Jefferson Davis?)And Marvel let this through, and no one thought it was a bad idea.

And here comes Into The Spiderverse, where they could have taken the opportunity to change it, because it’s comics and they change every goddamn thing in comics, but nope, they left that shit in there.

I still can’t get over this. This is why we need black voices telling black stories, if only so we don’t get a black super hero named Robert Lee.

“My Uncle Ben said that if I don’t have anything nice to say, then I shouldn’t say anything at all…but my Uncle Ben isn’t here and you’re a weenie!”

-Peter Parker

blog.name: greatrunner
blog.title: Give my Regards to the Inferno!
blog.description:
greatrunner | 30 | Sagittarius | Writer. | Professional Heel. | Formerly everyleaffallstoosoon and vemeer-mark-iv | banner: ironmacn

Hello, strange wanderer of the tumblrsphere of danger. This is a blogsphere for my personal likes and interests. If you're interested in what I happen to be interested in, check out my archive, tags and navigation. This is not a spoiler free zone, I usually don't mark spoilers. This blog contains blood, gore and body horror. Basically it contains content that isn’t for thirteen and under audiences, so please don’t follow me if you aren’t 18+. Thanks for visiting, tho.

summary: greatrunner’s favorite books of 2018 (in no particular rank/order): miles morales: spider man (jason reynolds) >> nanny returns...
caption:
greatrunner’s favorite books of 2018 (in no particular rank/order):

miles morales: spider man (jason reynolds) >> nanny returns (emma mclaughlin and nicola kraus) >> spider-man 2099, volume 2 (peter david) >> the books of elsewhere: the shadows (jacqueline west) >> spider-man 2099, volume 3 (peter david) >> the annotated african-american folktales (henry louis gate jr., maria tatar)

1.Miles Morales: Spider-Man – Jason Reynolds - (2018) – The Miles Morales story I would recommend newcomers of the character to read before touching the comics, Jason Reynolds’ YA slice-of-life novel focuses on characterizing Miles Morales to a degree that Brian Michael Bendis or his current writers couldn’t be arsed to do or wasn’t attempted (by non-Black writers) until Marvel’s Spider-Man, and makes me wish a series came out of this. It’s got its hiccups, but it’s good. Read it.

2. Nanny Returns - Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus - (2009) – Nanny Returns is probably an interesting case of the author who assumes a character has learned something, but nothing about their experience throughout the narrative really reflects – or earns that. Nan (a former Nanny who deals in conflict resolution for businesses) spends a grand majority of the novel towing the line of a toxic environment that breeds rampant bullying and victim blaming among young, rich and ignorant children of wealthy families, (because she wants money to fix up an old row house in a gentrified neighborhood), and it’s only by sheer luck that the circumstances she does nothing to change end up rectifying themselves through the hubris of a character that is barely present in the narrative. It’s such a train-wreck of a book, I couldn’t put it down, honestly. I could understand her perspective in the original novel, but here, she’s not remotely sympathetic (which wasn’t the author’s intent, clearly). It kinda makes me thankful the film for the first novel chose to end things with some kind of resolution (that was a direct result of the characters changing to some degree, lmao).

3. Spider-Man 2099 (Volume 2) – Peter David - (2014-2015) – The second volume of the once-defunct Spider-Man 2099 revitalizes the series with time travel shenanigans that pits Miguel O’Hara against events that radically alter his present (2099) reality and attempt to bring about some positive change in his biological grandfather (circa 2014). Spider-Man 2099 is probably the only Spider-Man title I can enjoy unabashedly without (major) issue because I think Peter David never lets it escape him how ridiculous the framework of his character’s circumstances is, but he’s never mean-spirited about it. On top of that, he surrounds Miguel with some fantastic supporting characters. Volume two is about twelve issues long (cut short by the Secret Wars event), but it’s a solid read and a good time with some fantastic artwork by William Sliney.

4. Spider-Man 2099 (Volume 3) – Peter David - (2015-2017) – The third volume of Spider-Man 2099 picks up where Spider-Man 2099, or Secret Wars 2099 and Secret Wars in general, left off. Miguel is still trying to repair the past, but now he’s dealing with the added stress of a romantic relationship with Tempest Monroe (no apparent relation to Storm) and his biological father (Tyler Stone) and the ever-changing world of 2099 actively trying to fuck things up for him. The series lasts up 25 or less issues and goes places I honestly wasn’t anticipating or expecting. Silney and David are on their A-game here and the conclusion left me wanting more – in a good way. It’s a relatively solid end to a series I never really expected would see the light of day again.

5. The Books of Elsewhere – The Shadows (Book 1) – Jacqueline West – (2010) - The Books of Elsewhere is an odd little children’s book that I saw being advertised on a short story website for the zombie apocalypse and reminded myself to keep in my the back of my mind the next time I went to the library. That sleepy reminder eventually kicked in and I borrowed it during the summer. The best impression I could give you is that it a lot like Coraline in the sense that it’s about a young girl who finds a hidden world inside an old house she and her family move into. What it lacks is the cautionary tale beyond your run of the mill child-experiences-hubris-then-fixes-mistake-caused-by-hubris. The combination of illustrations elevates the story that is fairly visual-reliant. There are like six or seven books in the series, I’m not sure if I’ll read them, but the first book ends conclusively enough that don’t really need to worry about what follows.

6. The Annotated African Folktales – Henry Louis Jr, etc. – (2017) - If you’re familiar with The Annotated Brothers Grimm, then The Annotated African-American Folktales should be a relatively easy read to get through depending on your investment in the folktales themselves. You get basic information regarding the history of the tale itself and chosen verbage, use of language and etc. It’s definitely the kind of book you want in your collection, particularly if you end up taking an African-American lit. class in college.
caption_abstract:
greatrunner’s favorite books of 2018 (in no particular rank/order):

miles morales: spider man (jason reynolds) >> nanny returns (emma mclaughlin and nicola kraus) >> spider-man 2099, volume 2 (peter david) >> the books of elsewhere: the shadows (jacqueline west) >> spider-man 2099, volume 3 (peter david) >> the annotated african-american folktales (henry louis gate jr., maria tatar)

summary:
*at school*
Ned: There's a spider, man!
Peter: NED WHAT THE F-
Ned: NO DUDE THERE'S LITERALLY A SPIDER ON YOUR BOOK
Peter: Oh....
body:
*at school*

Ned: There’s a spider, man!

Peter: NED WHAT THE F-

Ned: NO DUDE THERE’S LITERALLY A SPIDER ON YOUR BOOK

Peter: Oh. Oh my God. I thought you were outing me in an Italian accent.

reblog.comment:
*at school*

Peter: NED WHAT THE F-

Ned: NO DUDE THERE’S LITERALLY A SPIDER ON YOUR BOOK

Peter: Oh. Oh my God. I thought you were outing me in an Italian accent.

summary: Me, seeing that McFarlane’s leaving: :)))) Me, seeing that he’s getting replaced with a woman: :))))))))))))))) Me, seeing how...
body:
Me, seeing that McFarlane’s leaving: :))))

Me, seeing that he’s getting replaced with a woman: :)))))))))))))))

Me, seeing how she’s not only keeping to the theme of putting Peter down and the “I only do stuff bc of my guilt, even when the feeling or motivation I’m describing fits something else better” characterization, but also makes it as though Peter prefers Gwen over MJ: :((((((((((((((((((((((

Me, seeing that Erik Larsen is next: >:(((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((( (((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((

The only thing that saves you is that, since you put it in Thanos’s, the villain, mouth, I don’t know if you actually believe that heroes are the cause of villains. Also, why do Peter and Thanos both act as though Thanos has a say in whether someone dies or stays dead? And did Thanos actually revert to being a bad guy or did you just draft him? Why does he have the Infinity Gauntlet? Can I just disregard all of this as a near-death halloucination and get it over with?
